body.p:
I should have answered your several
communications long ere this, but business both private & public
prevented me from doing myself this pleasure. Now you would
justly say, that any man can write a few lines, however his
time may be monopolized by his avocation, and, with much pro=
priety you could instance it in your own person, whose time
being very limited, is yet able to carry on a correspondence
almost over the whole Union. I would answer you in few
words Hebrew!! Besides my principal reason for not having been more
prompt is, that I determined never to appear before you empty handed,
viz, without contributing something to the Occident, and thus I offer
you the enclosed trifle which you may insert in your invaluable journal
if you find it worthy to have a place therein, and good enough to
stand the scrutiny of the criticising public. As regards the
proposed convention, I hope to give you soon more fully my opinion
on it, for I can assure that I anticipated such results. Mr Hart
has no doubt acquainted you with the fact, that the Congregation
Shearit Israel will not join the Convention. You are doubtlessly dis
appointed, and I am really sorry that your zeal and honest
endeavors in the good cause are so little appreciated by our
brethern, and the, so much cherished, hope of affecting a Union
of Israel in the United States will have to be relinquished for the
present

But there is one consolation that the matter rests in good hands
for as far as I have the honor of knowing you by reputation,
I know that you are not the man to give up a project so
easily, if there is the remotest spark of hope, of succeeding
even at an indefinite period, and as far as I am con
cerned, I promise you my aid, as much as my feeble efforts
will permit, so that if the congregation can retain me here I hope yet to
see Charleston formost in the successful effort. It strikes me
however, that you could further the matter by the following method.
Engage if possible a competent person, friendly to the cause,
who is to issue an anonymous Article, showing all imaginable
dangers which ultras? think may possibly accrue to the cause of our holy Religion
by the proposed convention, let it be worded as if coming from
a hostile pen, and then set about depending anonymously the project, ably,
at the same time laying bare every imaginable disadvantage we
are laboring under at present and the deplorable state of religious
anarchy amongst Israel all over America. Such a controversy would
draw the attention of the public more successfully, those who
are lukewarm may become interested in the matter, while the
ultra Orthodox will gradually yield. I merely suggest this
because there are many here and probably everywhere else, who will not
listen to reason, and merely say, It cannot be done. One
objects because his neighbor says it is injurious, the other, because
it will cost something, a third, wishes to show the public
that he possess wisdom, and foresight. In short there are but
precious few who oppose the measure from true religions

motives. Selfishness, lukewarmness, and the natural disposition
of our people to oppose are the stumbling blocks in our
way, but we must nevertheless keep on and steadily pursue
the true course, and we cannot fail. There are little news
here which interest you, except that next thursday a concert
is to be given in behalf our congregation may the Lord
grant them success for the congregation is much in need of
pecuniary aid. By the by, I was informed yesterday that
D Landsberg, who was expected to succeed Mr Poznanski, re=
fuses coming, for several reasons, the principal of which
are, that he expected $500.00 for travelling expenses, and they
only sent him $200.00 and again, he only wishes to be minis=
ter and not Chazan. There is besides a great deal of contention
amongst them, and Mr P. has lost ground even amongst his
own party. Hoping that this may find you in the enjoyment
of the best of health, and fervently wishing that the Lord
may prolong your days for the Benefit of our Brethern and the cause.
